body:
None of the observed behavior is acceptable FMPOV. From what you describe, I see multiple issues we should probably address:

1. As you already mentioned, closing the connection also entails discarding of the registration assertion. Given the cost at which it needs to be created, one could ask whether it makes sense to close the connection at all once the adapter runs out of credits. On the other hand, closing the connection may trigger the client to (re-)connect to another adapter instance which hopefully has credits available.
1. The adapters currently assume that the registry is always available for issuing an assertion. However, IIRC the device registry just hands out 20 credits to an adapter for issuing requests. I think this will prove to be a bottleneck in the scenario described by you when hundreds of devices re-connect and send their first message. We should probably take precautions in the adapters to refuse messages if there are no credits available for requesting assertions from the Device Registration service.

In any case, your expectation regarding the system remaining in a stable state and degrading gracefully is more than appropriate.

Actually I think **running out of credits** should not be considered as an error case , but rather as a situation that at least every once in a while happens as normal behaviour.

Thus to close the connection to the client in such a case sounds to me like a "brutal" reaction - especially if the client did not misbehave at all, but only too many devices of the same tenant just sent data via the affected protocol adapter instance.

So, +1 for not closing the connection when running out of credits.

But I am not sure about why this should be configurable: I guess the configuration would then behave like it is now and disconnects the device? So if overload is the source of running out of credits, a large number of devices would constantly reconnect and jump through all adapter instances?
I would think this behaviour is hardly ever desired - rather more sophisticated strategies (like no single device can completely prevent other devices at the same adapter coming through with their payload) could be a midterm-solution.
WDYT?

I am with @sysexcontrol and think running out of credits is a normal case and should not end in disconnection. The case that this might be true for a longer time, is something we need to figure out and how to handle it. So I think we should start with not closing the connection and collect experiences with this. If we make this configurable we do not have a real solution but a bigger amount of possible system states, which makes understanding of the system as a whole harder.

issue.title: Define Device Registration and Credentials APIs based on REST
issue.body:
Currently the [Device Registration](https://www.eclipse.org/hono/api/Device-Registration-API/) and [Credentials](https://www.eclipse.org/hono/api/Credentials-API/) APIs are (officially) defined based upon the AMQP protocol.

These APIs are not relying on AMQP features though. Using a REST-based definition instead would be an easier and more straightforward approach concerning the implementation and usage of these APIs.

When the Credentials API REST implementation is complete, both API specification documents could be rewritten to refer to the REST-based APIs. 
The AMQP implementation could possibly then be removed. Having only one implementation would also mean less maintenance effort.

body:
Unluckily, MQTT 3.1.1 doesn't have a way for providing errors to the client (it will be addressed with MQTT v5) and the only way is to close connection if errors occur.
In this specific case I agree on not closing the connection but just because we are supporting only "AT MOST ONCE" delivery so the client can expect that a packet is lost and is not delivered to the service.
If we'll move to support telemetry with "AT LEAST ONCE" then we can't just drop the message when the adapter runs out of credits.
For now, +1 for not closing the connection.

I agree as well. For me it seems natural to just drop telemetry messages if there's no credit. For event (and other QoS1) messages, we should drop the message and not send puback back. IIRC that should indicate to the client that message is not received and it can try to redeliver it after a timeout.

> For event (and other QoS1) messages, we should drop the message and not send puback back. IIRC that should indicate the client that message is not received and it can try to redeliver after a timeout.

I agree with @dejanb, even for QoS 1 we do not need to close the connection, we just do not send the PUBACK. This is already implemented.

I will then change the code accordingly, i.e. do not close the connection if we run out of credits (regardless of whether it is credits for Registration or Hono Messaging).

Thanks for your opinion, guys :+1:

Yes I agree with @dejanb regarding QoS 1, I made a mistake saying that "we can't just drop the message" ... the good idea is dropping message and not sending the PUBACK hoping that the adapter will receive more credit in the future.
